title: 107_s686
content: The "Resource Efficient Appliance Incentives Act" provides a tax credit for energy-efficient appliances under section 45E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Resource Efficient Appliance Incentives Act" offers a tax credit for energy-efficient appliances produced by the taxpayer during the taxable year. The credit amount is based on the number of qualified appliances produced, such as energy-efficient clothes washers and refrigerators. The tax credit for energy-efficient appliances is based on the number of appliances produced by the taxpayer during the year, with a maximum credit limit of $30,000,000 for each type of appliance. The tax credit for energy-efficient appliances is limited to 2 percent of the taxpayer's average annual gross receipts for the previous three years. A qualified energy efficient appliance includes energy efficient clothes washers and refrigerators. An efficient clothes washer is a residential washer with a 1.26 MEF or 1.42 MEF for energy efficiency. An energy-efficient refrigerator is a defrost refrigerator with a volume of at least 16.5 cubic feet and consumes 10% less energy than standard. The Department of Energy sets energy conservation standards for refrigerators, requiring them to consume 15% less energy than the 2001 standards. Special rules apply, and taxpayers must provide necessary information to claim the credit amount. The section outlines the termination of the energy efficient appliance credit for certain products produced after specific calendar years. Additionally, it limits the carryback of the credit before a specified effective date. The text discusses the termination of the energy efficient appliance credit for certain products and limits the carryback of the credit before a specified effective date. It also includes conforming and clerical amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The energy efficient appliance credit under Sec. 45E applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
